weeklyAlbums.title: Beethoven: Symphony No. 5
weeklyAlbums.description: The legendary recording that defines this symphony. Kleiber's electric intensity brings out every detail of Beethoven's vision—from the famous four-note motif to the triumphant finale.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: This is THE recording to understand why Beethoven 5 matters. Kleiber's tempo choices and dynamic control are revelatory.

keyMoments.description: The famous fate motif—four notes that drive everything
The bridge from darkness to the triumphant finale

weeklyAlbums.title: Bach: Goldberg Variations
weeklyAlbums.description: Gould's final studio recording—slower, more profound than his famous 1955 debut. Thirty variations of infinite beauty and intellectual depth.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: Experience Bach's architecture through a master pianist's mature vision. The 1981 version has depth that reveals itself over many listens.

keyMoments.description: The Aria—the theme from which all grows

weeklyAlbums.title: Debussy: Orchestral Works
weeklyAlbums.description: La Mer, Prélude à l'après-midi d'un faune, and Nocturnes in luminous performances. The colors of Impressionism captured perfectly.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: If you think classical music is heavy and formal, this will change your mind. Debussy is pure color and atmosphere.

keyMoments.description: La Mer opens with the sea at dawn
Prélude—the famous flute melody evoking a faun's dream

weeklyAlbums.title: Chopin: Nocturnes
weeklyAlbums.description: All 21 Nocturnes performed with aristocratic poise and deep feeling. The perfect introduction to Romantic piano music.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: Chopin invented the piano nocturne. These pieces are the soul of Romantic pianism—beauty without excess.

keyMoments.description: Op. 48 No. 1—a nocturne with dramatic depth

weeklyAlbums.title: Mozart: Requiem
weeklyAlbums.artist: John Eliot Gardiner / English Baroque Soloists
weeklyAlbums.description: Mozart's unfinished masterpiece in a lean, dramatic performance on period instruments. The Dies Irae is terrifying; the Lacrimosa is heartbreaking.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: Mozart died writing this work. The combination of mortality and divine beauty makes it uniquely powerful.

keyMoments.description: Dies Irae—the Day of Wrath explodes

weeklyAlbums.title: Vivaldi: The Four Seasons
weeklyAlbums.description: A historically-informed performance that strips away centuries of heavy interpretation. The result is vivid, immediate, and exciting.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: You've heard Four Seasons in every coffee shop—but not like this. Period instruments reveal Vivaldi's original colors.

keyMoments.description: Winter's icy chill and warmth by the fire

weeklyAlbums.title: Brahms: Symphony No. 4
weeklyAlbums.description: Another Kleiber miracle. The fourth symphony's autumnal melancholy and final passacaglia are rendered with perfect balance of structure and emotion.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: Brahms' final symphony is a meditation on endings. The last movement's variations are among the greatest pages in all music.

weeklyAlbums.title: Stravinsky: The Rite of Spring
weeklyAlbums.description: The work that changed music forever, in a performance of crystalline clarity. Every explosive rhythm and strange harmony is perfectly balanced.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: This caused a riot at its 1913 premiere. A century later, it still sounds revolutionary.

keyMoments.description: The Augurs of Spring—pounding, dissonant chords

weeklyAlbums.title: Tchaikovsky: Swan Lake Suite
weeklyAlbums.description: The essence of the beloved ballet in orchestral highlights. The famous theme, the dance of the cygnets, and the tragic finale.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: Pure Romantic melody and orchestral color. Tchaikovsky's gift for tune-writing is on full display.

keyMoments.description: The iconic swan theme on oboe
Dance of the Little Swans—delightful precision

weeklyAlbums.title: Handel: Messiah (Highlights)
weeklyAlbums.description: Period-instrument performance bringing freshness to the beloved oratorio. The Hallelujah Chorus as you've never heard it.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: This isn't just Christmas music. Handel's drama and melody speak to everyone.

weeklyAlbums.title: Ravel: Piano Concerto in G
weeklyAlbums.artist: Krystian Zimerman / Pierre Boulez / Cleveland Orchestra
weeklyAlbums.description: Jazz-inflected brilliance meets French elegance. The slow movement is one of the most beautiful things Ravel ever wrote.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: Proof that 20th-century classical music can be immediately appealing. The slow movement will haunt you.

keyMoments.description: The whip crack that opens the work

weeklyAlbums.title: Dvorak: Symphony No. 9 'From the New World'
weeklyAlbums.description: A Czech composer's love letter to America, performed by a Czech émigré conductor. The famous Largo is unforgettable.
weeklyAlbums.whyListen: One of the most approachable symphonies ever written. The melodies feel like folk songs you already know.

keyMoments.description: Introduction building to the main theme
The Largo—'Going Home' melody on English horn

monthlySpotlights.title: Johann Sebastian Bach
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: The Foundation of Western Music
monthlySpotlights.description: January we explore the composer who is the foundation of everything that came after. Bach's mastery of counterpoint, harmony, and form established the grammar of Western classical music.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to one complete Brandenburg Concerto each week

monthlySpotlights.title: The Romantic Era
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: When Music Became Personal
monthlySpotlights.description: February—the month of love—belongs to the Romantics. This era freed music from courtly restraint and let composers pour out their souls.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Compare the same emotion expressed by three different Romantic composers

monthlySpotlights.title: Ludwig van Beethoven
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: The Revolutionary
monthlySpotlights.description: March is for revolution—and no composer was more revolutionary than Beethoven. From the Classical elegance of his early works to the radical late quartets, witness music's transformation.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to symphonies 1, 5, and 9 to hear Beethoven's evolution

monthlySpotlights.title: The Baroque Era
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: Ornament, Drama, and Grandeur
monthlySpotlights.description: April brings spring's ornate blossoms—and the Baroque's ornate music. Discover the era when opera was born and counterpoint reached its peak.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Learn to identify the basso continuo in three different Baroque works

monthlySpotlights.title: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: Divine Grace
monthlySpotlights.description: Mozart's music sparkles like spring turning to summer. His seeming effortlessness conceals profound depth. This month, we look past the genius myth to the real music.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Compare Mozart's opera writing with his instrumental writing

monthlySpotlights.title: The Symphony
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: The Pinnacle of Orchestral Art
monthlySpotlights.description: June celebrates the grandest of forms. From Haydn's invention through Mahler's expansion, trace how composers used the symphony to express their deepest thoughts.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to the first movements of three symphonies and identify sonata form

monthlySpotlights.title: Frédéric Chopin
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: The Poet of the Piano
monthlySpotlights.description: Summer evenings call for Chopin's nocturnes. The most pianistic of composers created works that seem to breathe and sing.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to nocturnes at different times of day and note how they feel different

monthlySpotlights.title: The Modern Era
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: Breaking All the Rules
monthlySpotlights.description: August heat brings radical change. Explore how 20th-century composers shattered expectations and created entirely new sound worlds.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to one 'difficult' modern work three times and track how your perception changes

monthlySpotlights.title: Johannes Brahms
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: The Romantic Classicist
monthlySpotlights.description: As fall begins, we turn to Brahms' autumnal warmth. He fused Romantic passion with Classical architecture in works of immense power.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: The Brahms Symphonies Challenge: Listen to all four symphonies this month

monthlySpotlights.title: Opera
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: When Music Tells Stories
monthlySpotlights.description: October's drama calls for opera. From Mozart's comedies to Wagner's myths, discover how composers used voices and orchestra to tell humanity's greatest stories.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Watch one opera with subtitles—then listen again without visuals

monthlySpotlights.title: Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: Heart on Sleeve
monthlySpotlights.description: November's approaching holidays bring Tchaikovsky—master of melody and the composer of The Nutcracker. Experience Russian Romanticism at its most direct.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to The Nutcracker while following the story

monthlySpotlights.title: The Requiem
monthlySpotlights.subtitle: Music for Eternity
monthlySpotlights.description: December invites reflection. The Requiem—music for the dead—is paradoxically some of the most life-affirming music ever written.
monthlySpotlights.challenge: Listen to all three requiems and compare how each composer approaches mortality
